The other dinosaurs just thought he was waving. Poor guy, always misunderstood. And then, well, you know how that story ends. No more road crossings for him.

What do you call a lazy dinosaur? A Brontosnore-us! He loved to just lie around, basking in the sun, occasionally munching on a leaf or two. His friends would try to get him to go on adventures, but he'd just yawn and say, 'Too much effort, I'll just wait for the next extinction event to catch up on my sleep.' And catch up he did! He's probably still snoring, somewhere in the fossil record. They say his snores were so loud, they caused minor earthquakes. No wonder all the other dinosaurs were so jumpy.

Why did the woolly mammoth get fired from the ice cream shop? Because he kept hogging all the sprinkles! He just couldn't resist them. Every time a customer ordered a cone, he'd sneak a few extra handfuls for himself. His boss kept telling him, 'Mammoth, you're going to eat us out of business!' But he just couldn't help it. His tusks were also a bit of a problem behind the counter; kept knocking over the toppings. Eventually, they had to let him go. He went on to open his own frozen yogurt stand, where sprinkles were unlimited. It was a huge success, until... well, you know.

Did you hear about the dinosaur who opened a bakery? He called it 'Jurassic Bakes.' His specialty was giant cookies, but he had a hard time getting customers because everyone was afraid he'd eat them instead of their pastries. He tried to reassure them, 'Don't worry, I'm a herbivore! I only eat plants!' But his roar tended to scare away even the bravest of sweet-toothed cavemen. Plus, his oven was a volcano, which made timing a bit tricky. His sourdough was legendary, though, probably because of the volcanic ash he accidentally kneaded in. He eventually went out of business when the meteor hit, which, ironically, was great for his sourdough starter.

Why don't Pterodactyls play hide-and-seek? Because they're always soaring so high, you can see them from a mile away! It's really hard to find a good hiding spot when you're a giant flying reptile. They tried hiding behind clouds, but then their shadows gave them away. They even tried camouflaging themselves as mountains, but their squawking was a dead giveaway. Their friends would always just point up and say, 'Found you, Terry!' It was a bit demoralizing. Eventually, they just gave up on the game and stuck to flying around, admiring the view, and occasionally swooping down to grab a fish. Much less frustrating.

A self-help guru stood before a massive crowd. 'The key to success,' he boomed, 'is to never give up! Never surrender! Always push forward!' A man in the front row raised his hand. Then I tried to tell my cat to stop shedding on the couch, but she just yawned and stretched, clearly unimpressed by my newfound assertiveness. I think I need a self-help book for my cat.

He just couldn't seem to hold onto a job, much like some people can't hold onto their bladder after a large coffee. It's a real *draining* experience, trying to find your calling, especially when your current job is just a *flush* in the pan. He eventually found his true calling as a plumber, because he was always good at handling *flow*.

My doctor told me I need to start drinking more water. I said, "But doctor, I already drink like, a gallon a day!" He looked at me, a little concerned, and said, "Well, that explains why you've been in here every hour on the hour today." I told him, "Yeah, it's a real *stream* of consciousness, this whole hydration thing." He just sighed and handed me a pamphlet about bladder control. I guess I'm just really good at *flushing* out toxins, maybe a little too good. It's a tough life, being so hydrated, especially when every public restroom is a marathon.

What do you call a pile of cats? A meow-ntain! What do you call a pile of cats that just ate a lot of spicy food? A purr-gatory! Just like when you're holding it in during a long car ride, and then suddenly, you hit a bump. That's when the real *feline* instinct kicks in, and you realize you should have stopped an hour ago. It's a classic tale of nature calling, and you finally answering, perhaps a little too late.

I went to a fancy restaurant last night and ordered the clam chowder. It was so thick, I swear it could have walked off the table! I told the waiter, "This chowder is so rich, it probably has its own trust fund!" He just smiled and said, "Sir, that's our special 'thick and hearty' recipe." I said, "Hearty is right, I feel like I just ate a brick! My stomach is doing more gurgling than a leaky faucet." It was a real *gut* feeling that I should have ordered something lighter. Now I'm just hoping my internal plumbing can handle this culinary challenge. Wish me luck on the *digestive journey*!

Why don't scientists trust atoms? Because they make up everything! And what about when atoms need to go to the bathroom? They just *ionize*! It's a very scientific process, you see. They just release all their excess energy, and poof! A little atomic relief. It's not as messy as us humans, with our complicated plumbing and urgent needs. They don't have to worry about finding a clean restroom or running out of toilet paper. They just do their business and move on, like the tiny, efficient particles they are. We could learn a thing or two from their simple, yet effective, *molecular movements*.

prompt: Tell me a joke about space

responses.text: Why did the sun go to school? To get brighter! But seriously, space is a pretty dark place, isn't it? Except for all the stars, of course. And the galaxies. And the nebulae. Okay, maybe it's not that dark. It's actually quite illuminating, don't you think? Like a cosmic disco ball, but instead of flashing lights, it's exploding stars. Much more exciting than school, I reckon. Although, learning about black holes is pretty mind-bending. They say if you stare into the abyss, the abyss stares back. But what if the abyss is a black hole? Does it just suck you in with its gaze? Probably. That's why I prefer looking at pretty pictures of space from a safe distance. No existential dread, just cosmic wonder.

Why don't scientists trust atoms? Because they make up everything! And in space, they make up even more things, like giant gas clouds and entire planets. It's mind-boggling, really. You think you understand something, and then you learn about quantum mechanics and suddenly gravity seems like a friendly hug. I heard a joke once that a neutron walks into a bar and asks, 'How much for a drink?' The bartender replies, 'For you, no charge.' Get it? No charge! Because neutrons are neutral. I always thought that was a pretty good one. Almost as good as the universe itself, which, let's be honest, is the ultimate punchline.

What do you call a lazy kangaroo in space? Pouch potato! I know, I know, it's a bit of a stretch, but so is the universe! Think about it, the distances are so vast, even light takes years to travel. Imagine if you were a kangaroo out there, just hopping along, and you realized it would take you a million years to get to the next galaxy. You'd probably just give up and become a pouch potato too. Or maybe you'd invent a faster-than-light pouch. Now that's an invention I could get behind. Especially if it came with snacks. Space snacks are probably just freeze-dried ice cream though, which is a bit disappointing.

Why did the alien break up with the astronaut? Because he needed more space! It's a classic, but it still makes me chuckle. Imagine the awkward conversation: 'Look, it's not you, it's me... I just need to orbit a bit more, you know? Explore other galaxies. It's not a commitment thing, it's a cosmic wanderlust thing.' And then the astronaut is left heartbroken, floating aimlessly in their spaceship, probably listening to some sad space ballads. Maybe they'll find love with a friendly robot. Robots are much less likely to need 'more space,' unless it's for their internal wiring. And even then, they usually have enough.

What's an astronaut's favorite part of a computer? The space bar! Get it? Because they're in space! And they use computers! It’s a match made in... well, not heaven, but definitely somewhere with good Wi-Fi. I always wonder what kind of internet speed they get up there. Probably pretty stellar, pun intended. Imagine trying to stream a movie from Mars. The buffering would be out of this world! But at least they have a good excuse for their slow connection. 'Sorry, my dear, the cosmic rays are interfering with the signal today.' Sounds much more glamorous than 'my router needs a reboot.'
